sections.title: Portfolio Construction Principles
sections.content:
A dividend portfolio isn't just a collection of high-yield stocks. It's a carefully constructed mix of companies across different sectors, with varying yields and growth rates, designed to provide reliable and growing income.

The goal is diversificationâ€”not just in number of stocks, but in income sources. If all your dividend stocks are in one sector (like energy), a sector downturn could devastate your income.

points.title: Number of Stocks: 20-30
points.description: Enough to diversify risk, but not so many you can't track them. Each position should be 3-5% of your portfolio. No single stock over 5%.

points.title: Sector Allocation
points.description: Spread across at least 8-10 sectors. No sector should exceed 20% of your portfolio. Include defensive sectors (utilities, consumer staples, healthcare) for stability.

points.title: Yield Mix
points.description: Blend high-yield stocks (4-6%) with dividend growers (2-3% yield, 10%+ growth). This balances current income with future income growth.

points.title: Geographic Diversification
points.description: Consider 10-20% in international dividend stocks. Many foreign companies pay higher yields than US counterparts.

points.title: REITs Allocation
points.description: Real Estate Investment Trusts offer high yields (4-6%) and diversification from traditional stocks. Limit to 10-15% of portfolio due to interest rate sensitivity.

sections.title: Sector Allocation for Dividend Investors
sections.content:
Different sectors have different dividend characteristics:

Defensive Sectors (Higher Yields, Slower Growth):
- Utilities: 3-4% yields, stable but slow growth
- Consumer Staples: 2.5-3.5% yields, recession-resistant
- Healthcare: 2-3% yields, aging population tailwind

Cyclical Sectors (Variable):
- Financials: 2-4% yields, sensitive to interest rates
- Industrials: 2-3% yields, tied to economic cycles
- Energy: 3-6% yields, volatile with oil prices

Growth Sectors (Lower Yields, Higher Growth):
- Technology: 1-2% yields, but fast dividend growth
- Consumer Discretionary: 1-2% yields, economic sensitivity

High-Yield Sectors:
- REITs: 4-6% yields, required to pay 90% of income
- MLPs: 6-8% yields, complex tax treatment
- BDCs: 8-10% yields, higher risk

A balanced dividend portfolio includes exposure to multiple sectors, with heavier weights in defensive sectors for stability.

sections.title: Sample Dividend Portfolio
sections.content:
Here's a sample 20-stock dividend portfolio:

Consumer Staples (15%):
- Procter & Gamble (PG)
- Coca-Cola (KO)
- PepsiCo (PEP)

Healthcare (15%):
- Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)
- AbbVie (ABBV)
- Pfizer (PFE)

Financials (12%):
- JPMorgan Chase (JPM)
- BlackRock (BLK)

Industrials (10%):
- 3M (MMM)
- Caterpillar (CAT)

Technology (10%):
- Microsoft (MSFT)
- Apple (AAPL)

Utilities (10%):
- NextEra Energy (NEE)
- Duke Energy (DUK)

Energy (8%):
- Chevron (CVX)
- ExxonMobil (XOM)

REITs (10%):
- Realty Income (O)
- Digital Realty (DLR)

Telecom (5%):
- Verizon (VZ)

Consumer Discretionary (5%):
- Home Depot (HD)

This portfolio yields approximately 3% with 6-8% dividend growth potential.

sections.title: Building Your Dividend Portfolio
steps: Determine your income goal - how much annual dividend income do you want?
Calculate required portfolio size - divide income goal by target yield (e.g., $12,000 / 3% = $400,000)
Choose your sector allocation based on your risk tolerance and income needs
Select 2-3 quality dividend stocks per sector using the evaluation criteria from Lesson 2
Start with your highest-conviction picks and add positions over time
Invest equal amounts in each position initially (equal-weight)
Enable dividend reinvestment (DRIP) to compound your returns
Rebalance annually to maintain target allocations

sections.title: The Power of DRIP
sections.content: Dividend Reinvestment Plans (DRIP) automatically use your dividends to buy more shares. Over 30 years, reinvesting dividends can triple your total return compared to taking cash. Enable DRIP in your brokerage account settings.

sections.title: Dividend ETFs as Building Blocks
sections.content:
If picking 20-30 individual stocks seems overwhelming, dividend ETFs offer instant diversification:

Broad Dividend ETFs:
- VYM (Vanguard High Dividend Yield): 400+ stocks, ~3% yield
- SCHD (Schwab US Dividend Equity): 100 stocks, ~3.5% yield, quality focus
- VIG (Vanguard Dividend Appreciation): Dividend growers, ~2% yield

High-Yield ETFs:
- HDV (iShares Core High Dividend): ~3.5% yield
- SPYD (SPDR Portfolio S&P 500 High Dividend): ~4.5% yield

Dividend Growth ETFs:
- DGRO (iShares Core Dividend Growth): Focus on dividend growth
- NOBL (ProShares S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats): Only Aristocrats

A simple approach: 70% SCHD + 30% VIG gives you high-quality dividend stocks with a blend of yield and growth.

sections.title: Key Takeaway
sections.content: Diversification is essential for dividend investors. Spread your income across sectors, blend yield with growth, and don't let any single stock dominate your portfolio. A well-diversified dividend portfolio can weather market storms while providing growing income.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.content: You now know how to build a diversified dividend portfolio. In the next lesson, we'll cover dividend reinvestment strategies and how to maximize the compounding effect of your dividends.
